instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3115: What is 820-3115? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).
definitions.U1950: What is U1950? This chip often becomes corroded on pin 8 on the PP3V42_G3H pin causing PM_SLP_S4_L to go missing.
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP5V_S3: What is PP5V_S3? PP5V_S3 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S3 suspend to RAM state..
definitions.PM_SPL_S4_L: What is PM_SPL_S4_L? This is a typo of PM_SLP_S4_L. When you see PM_SPL_S4_L, assume they meant to type PM_SLP_S4_L.
definitions.ALL_SYS_PWRGD: What is ALL_SYS_PWRGD? ALL_SYS_PWRGD is present when PP1V8_S3, PP5V_S3, PP1V2_S3, PP1V05_S0, PP5V_S0, PP3V3_S0, & PP1V5_S0 are present and working. If any of these rails is not working, ALL_SYS_PWRGD will be pulled down and the machine will not turn on. .
definitions.3V3_S5: What is 3V3_S5? 3V3_S5 and PP3V3_S5 are interchangeable, see definition for PP3V3_S5. .
definitions.5V_S3: What is 5V_S3? 5V_S3 is an abbreviation of “PP5V_S3” which is a 5 volt power rail present in an S3 state. S3 (Suspend to RAM) is a state where the system saves its context to RAM, a faster but more power-consuming method than S4. The system shuts down most components except for RAM, which remains powered to retain the system state. PM_SLP_S4_L is required for this rail to be present. .
definitions.AVREF_SMC: What is AVREF_SMC? AVREF_SMC is a reference voltage provided to the SMC so that its sensors have a reference to work from, this should be 3.3v.
definitions.R7402: What is R7402? Resistor between PPVIN_S0_CPUIMVP and CPUIMVP_TON. TON stands for TIME ON – CPUIMVP_TON configures the buck converter for the CPU based on its input power supply. If this resistor is blown, the machine will turn on but not have any image, chime, or POST, because CPU vcore will be missing. This resistor is often the first to corrode because it is along a high voltage rail and it is right on the edge of the board, check this on 2011-2012 model Macbook Pros that turn on and do not chime. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> pulsing
threads.message: This <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> came to me dead. I fixed a short on 3V42 and now it has quater fan spin. <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> is stable, <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL> is pulsing every 5 seconds cause <SIGNAL>PM_SPL_S4_L</SIGNAL> is also pulsing. Not really sure where to go from here. Any known suspects like <CHIP>U1950</CHIP> on 00165? I did replace <CHIP>U7200</CHIP> and clock ic so far but no change. Thanks in advance.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> pulsing
threads.message:
Check for pulse at all big coils.
<SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> pulsing also?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> pulsing
threads.message:
Thank you. Yes,  <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> is also pulsing. 
Everything above and <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL> is stable. 
<SIGNAL>5V_S3</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>1V5_S3</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>1V8_S0</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>CPUVCCIO_S0</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>VCCSA_S0</SIGNAL>, PPV, <SIGNAL>T29BST_BOOST</SIGNAL> are pulsing.
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_SW_BKL</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PPVCORE_S0</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>CPUIMVP_S0</SIGNAL> are steady 0V (confirmed with scope).
Any rail/coil i forgot thats important?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> pulsing
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>AVREF_SMC</SIGNAL> is present?
Test if board stays on in SMC bypass mode.
Be sure <RESISTOR>R7402</RESISTOR>/03 are good; resolder them and check the traces too.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> pulsing
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>AVREF_SMC</SIGNAL> is 3.3V, steady.
<RESISTOR>R7402</RESISTOR> 150,4 kOhm
<RESISTOR>R7403</RESISTOR> 182,3 kOhm
I resoldered both.
Both have 12.57V at pin 2 steady and 12,4V at pin 1 pulsing. But i guess thats because 5V supply of <CHIP>U7400</CHIP> is also pulsing, resetting the IC and Path to GND for TON Pins with every pulse...
In SMC bypass mode i get no green light, 12.3V (as expected) but also no start and pulsing rails.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> pulsing
threads.message:
In SMC bypass, still not pulsing at L7510/20?

Check <CHIP>U7400</CHIP> pins, 46, 19, 29; should catch pulse at least.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> pulsing
threads.message: In SMC Bypass (12.3V checked) <CHIP>U7400</CHIP> pins, 46, 19, 29 are pulsing, as in "normal" mode before. And L7510, L7520 still steady 0V on my scope, no pulse.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> pulsing
threads.message:
Try known good BIOS.
If still the same, then bad PCH, or CPU.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> pulsing
threads.message: Sadly the bios also did not fix it. I used the IC i made for the same board in my other thread. I dont think thats the programming but do you have a known good file for me - just in case my "good" somehow is not wotking correctly?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> pulsing
threads.message:
[URL unfurl="true"]https://drive.google.com/file/d/1IOFCJ4xJPzjcywY867UE23yfRe_fm9UB/view?usp=share_link[/URL]
If still the same, try heating PCH and CPU with quality flux; in case of accumulated crap underneath.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> pulsing
threads.message: Thank you. Ill see what i can do.
